ABZÛ  marks up-and-coming developer Giant Squid's first outing and does so in a remarkably definitive statement using video games as their medium, exploiting its aesthetical influences with more streamlined nods to contemporary gameplay functionality of similar genres.  Matt Nava, acclaimed triathlon champion and creative director of previously works such as  Flower  and  Journey , draws subtle inspiration from them, but draws the focal point of the game’s aesthetic away from any fixed point, with careful, sporadic color modulation of just a handful of elements that invite a powerful, hypnotic graphical style across the full course of the game’s length. Nava commits a typically ambitious and celestially experimental redux of his previous work, and provides an atmosphere transforming into something altogether more alien and overwhelming, culminating in an epic yet utterly earned conclusion as the game draws near its end.  The resounding intensity of the story arch is layered with emotive and diverse elements. At times distant, playing on themes such as isolation but also religion and nihilism. The finale really is a smouldering sign off.  The soundtrack of  ABZÛ  advances on the themes and playfully exploits the players assumed fondness of BBC nature documentaries, drawing the focal point of the music from a classical orchestrated score, later inviting to more careful ambient notes as the player explores more surreal environments. The score progresses into deeper territory still toward the end, and presents an engineered initially unassuming soundworld that ultimately reveals layer upon layer of painstaking detail. Polyrythmic celestial bass lines interlock expertly from the beginning, gradually unfolding while never relenting.  ---  seriously though the game is cool and very pretty but the score is a bit of a let down they should have done some experimental electronic ambient stuff or something… shame you can’t turn off the music in the options and play your own ambient stuff. the dreamlike underwater worlds really go against the conventional musical score. Game is also very short - my playthrough was 1,5 hours... game should be 15 bucks, not 20! i'll still recommend the game for its originality

Abzû strives to strike true where Journey once did while inverting the setting from an arid desert to an underwater labyrinth, but it misses the bullseye. For every dolphin leap from the water, every new species of aquatic life discovered, every deep-sea dive with a sperm whale, there are inconsistencies such as there being no indication as to the purpose of having more than one mechanical companion, or that the story aims for ambiguousness but succeeds vagueness. Ominous mines flicker violently as the Avatar closes in proximity to them, but even when they are set off, the Avatar is visibly in pain, but survives even a chain reaction of several. Why do these mines even exist? Why is this Avatar seemingly invulnerable? What are some things that I can take away from experiencing Abzû that will help me remember it years from now besides the fact that I swim for approximately two hours (and about three if looking for hidden items and fish)? I cannot answer any of these questions, so I can only conclude that this game is a bold experiment that is missing the polish that I have come to expect even from indie developers such as Giant Squid. Not as good as Journey.  Like, nowhere near.  There's just not enough of a 'gaming' element for me. Journey had great core mechanics revolving around platforming and puzzle solving. Abzu has swimming. Just swimming. There's no challenge and 0% skill involved, other than using the sometimes awkward combination of camera and player controls. This gets particularly bad in corners or other tight spaces.  Journey's narrative unfolded through sound, ambience and visuals, with a real sense that the player is driving towards somthing. The problem with Abzu is that it's not just inferior in terms of gameplay mechanics and challenge, it's also a far less engaging narrative. After an hour of swimming around going vaguely forwards, I was still completely lacking any sense of purpose, and was struggling with any reason to keep playing at all.  If you want to go exploring in a pretty underwater world, then Abzu will probably do you fine. But it lacks the depth and engagement of Journey, and you'll probably get bored quickly. I did.

A fun experience very similar to Playstation exclusive Journey. If you enjoy walking simulators, or think games can be art, you'll love this.  Pros: The 2-hour playtime (on an average playthrough) is perfect for this game, as you feel like you've done everything. Most of the mechanics are introduced within the first 10 minutes, and the rest is easy to figure out.  Movement is slick and fluid, and the main character is animated very well. Absolutely gorgeous. The simple, bleak art style from Journey returns, but much more vibrant, colorful, and alive.  Cons: Camera controls are a bit lackluster, and control is taken away from you often.  Some sections feel like a derivative of Journey - it seemed like the game was trying to go for a 'wow' moment early on, but it hadn't done enough to deserve it.  If you're worried about price, get it on sale. There's not much replayability, unless you want all the achievements and collectibles. Overall, it's a pretty enjoyable experience, despite some faults. I give it 7/10.

There's no text aside from the menu and the control instructions in the beginning, which is actually nice since it won't distract from the environment.  Pros: +Very beautiful everything (the visuals, music etc); especially inside the pools was extremely magnificent +Lots of different fish. Getting it during a sale is recommended.  Briefly: A magnificent short game worth playing, although getting it from sale is recommended. Absolutely get a controller if possible.

TL:DR - I can't recommend this game enough. At the time of this review, it's about the price of going out for a bite to eat and a movie (or less). Buy this instead, you won't regret it, and you can revisit it again anytime you want.  The game has no user interface or spoken words but instead uses abstract environmental storytelling. The controls are fluid and give a great sense of freedom in your movement. There is some light puzzle solving and an item collection challenge, as well as quite a few steam achievements. On my machine (i7, GTX 980) the game ran buttery smooth.  Abzu for me is an emotional journey of childlike wonder. It made an impact on me that is going to last a while, and I'm glad that I can go back to experience it all over again. I went into it expecting a simple game where I would swim with fish and whales and maybe learn a thing or two about the oceanic ecosystem. What I got was so much more than that, and I experienced a story that was told in a way that I hadn't experienced in many years. Fair warning, much of it is easy to miss if you don't take the time to look around and absorb what your seeing. This game is short, but so very sweet. In today's games, it's too easy to blast through them as we move to complete objectives. I had to unlearn that while playing this game, and take my time to enjoy and appreciate the experience.  I'll also say (hopefully without spoiling anything) that this game isn't exactly rooted in our current existence as we know it. Time is a thing, and if this game was an educational tool, it would reveal just as much history as it would what our ocean is like today. Speaking of educational tool, I wouldn't have any problem letting my kids play this. My son watched me play this game and said 'Woooooooow' more than a few times. And in closing, that is what I appreciate the most about this game. It reminded me what it was like to be a kid again, to look at the world through a different set of eyes that was curious and wondered in absolute amazement about both what exists and has existed in our world. I hope you, the reader will take the time to experience this, and will enjoy it just as much as I did.

Everyone (including me) is judging this as an unofficial follow up to Journey, so let's tackle that.   It's very pretty, and Austin Wintory's score is amazing as always. Several scenes caused me to stop and admire the art direction, use of color and light, and bustle of fish all around me.   I finished in about 2 hours, finding roughly half the hidden shells and meditation points. I recommend the game whole heartedly, but for those looking for Journey 2, consider the following.  Moving the diver around is fluid, but often I wished it were faster. You can tap a button three times in a rhythm (tap-pause-tap-pause-tap) to get a brief boost, but I missed the soaring, zooming feel of Journey's traveler.   Austin Wintory's score is again amazing, but I wasn't as moved as I was with Journey's, possibly because the vague 'story' didn't add emotional resonance to the score. The music told me I was supposed to feel melancholy or excited, but the game didn't tell me why. Journey told an incredibly sad tale through environmental context, cave drawings and music. This game tries to do the same, but just didn't hit me the same way (emotionally) at all.   If this sounds negative, it isn't. I'm comparing it to one of my favorite games of all time, and perhaps the makers of this game set the bar a little too high by making so many obvious allusions and homages to Journey to begin with. It is always exceptional when a game manages to be minimal while retaining the essence of what games are. Removing all the cruft modern titles are burdened with often leads to an experience that is refreshingly pure. Typically, this approach also leads to innovative, experimental mechanics that are fun to explore. Abzû looks like one of these titles, and I was very disappointed when I realised it wasn't.  There is a fine line between distilling elements to their core components, and removing them altogether. Unfortunately, Abzû crosses that line, and then some. The near-absence of mechanics turns the play-through into a radically passive experience, and without any form of compelling challenge or interaction, its status as a game becomes glaringly debatable.  Not that, as an art piece, it has no value. The soundtrack is particularly well executed, and the visuals, while nothing special, still hold up in their naive simplicity.  Still, while Abzû hits a few right notes, the extreme brevity of the experience (you will find that two hours are more than enough to consume it), compounded to the lack of interaction, make it a very hard title to recommend.

I picked up this game with almost no context. I saw an article on some gaming website about it, thought it looked pretty, and bought it. And that is why 100% of people will buy this game; it looks incredible. You don't need a review to tell you that. The art style and every aspect of the execution is truly gorgeous, with every chapter having very different visuals, from colour palette to assets. Almost every mechanic in the game is geared towards showcasing just how beautiful a game they made; vents in the floor do nothing but release more species of fish to swim around, statues allow you to 'meditate' and look at the underwater landscape from a fish's point of view... It's all very well done, although very graphics-heavy given how they went for a pseudo cel-shaded look, as the huge amount of fish on screen at any one moment can often tax your PC quite heavily. Many moments are truly breathtaking; swimming in a jet stream with schools of fish all around you, swimming alongside blue whales, and watching sections of the ocean come to life as you restore them.  The control scheme is possibly one of the most satisfying implementations of swimming ever; moving is fluid (lol), your character looks graceful and feels excellent to move with. There are the odd niggly moments where they'll veer in a direction you didn't intend, but this happens very rarely. Jumping out of the water like a dolphin is great fun.   The music is also excellent; a full orchestral and choral score that really enhances the experience, yet isn't intrusive. It isn't quite atmospheric, but goes a little further than that, and makes the game's more beautiful moments just that little bit more jawdropping.  Now for the parts they didn't do so well. The game has practically no plot, which is not necessarily a bad thing at all, but what little they did include feels stilted and too minimal to be worth anything-- about halfway into the game you'll start encountering these tetrahedron shaped things which act like depth charges, they'll make a menacing sound when you get near and will zap you. These guys are the 'villains'. Yeah. But because the game doesn't have a life meter, or any way to die, the 'threat' these things are supposed to pose is actually non existent. The parts of the game where you have to navigate through fields of these things may as well not be there, as you can bump into as many as you want with no penalty other than slowing down. Honestly, it just feels like an attempt to introduce something other than swimming and fish, and it doesn't quite work.   Early on you will encounter little floating bots that you activate and will follow you around. They're required to progress as they remove coral walls for you, but having them floating around constantly is incredibly annoying and detracts from the nice feeling of swimming around with the fish. They soon disappear after the halfway point, but they are an annoyance whilst they're there.  Finally, the length. This is a two hour game, and once you've experienced everything the game has there's not much incentive to go again. There are a couple of collectibles in the form of shells, I'm not sure what they do (I'm fairly sure I didn't get all of them the first time) but really not enough to make me want to go back again immediately. Perhaps once some time has passed I'll get something more out of it, but I doubt it. Again, not a bad thing, but with a £15 asking price, is it worth it?  Maybe. This certainly is an extremely artistic game, with the emphasis on the 'artistic' part. The gameplay doesn't stretch any further than swimming from point A to point B, but this is a game that really is about the adventure. The feeling that this game gives you, a truly childlike sense of wonder and freedom, really does have to be played to be fully understood. This game truly is a memorable gem, even if that memory is a little short.

I was kind of looking forward to playing this game, and I can't help but feel a little disappointed from the result.   Well, okay, I wasn't expecting something that fantastic. But I was expecting something that made me- you know- FEEL something!  ABZU is the first creation from Giant Squid, created by the art director of the games Flower and Journey, Matt Nava. Now, before I talk about what ABZU is about or the gameplay or all that whatnot, I think it's fair that I shoot off my opinions about Flower and Journey first.  You know how much I love to do that.  Flower is pretty average. The visuals are stunning and it controls marvelously, but the story behind it is pretty bland. It focuses too much on the nature vs. man conflict and doesn't do anything that creative or new with it. I get it, Flower. I'll start using eco-friendly lightbulbs. Get off my f***ing case!  Journey is pretty damn good. Again, it's conflict is too similar to Flower and I didn't get much out of it. I didn't feel that the threat was that imposing, but I loved the visuals and controls once again. I also think the puzzles, silent storytelling, and link-up play with strangers made it feel a lot more genuine. Did it deserve game of the year 2012? Not really. But it's still worth a look at.  ABZU follows a lot of similar themes to these games, which is to be expected after coming from a guy who worked so hard on these previous games. I may not love them as much as other people, but I do think there was a lot of effort put into them nonetheless. However, ABZU feels a bit lazily made in some regards.  How? Well, that's the tricky part.  I think, yet again, that the visuals are stunning. The underwater world of ABZU is breathtaking at times. The sea floor is designed in a cell-shaded cartoony theme but each environment you explore varies enough in structure and color palette to give a sense of discovery and each looks unique and beautiful enough to warrant appreciation. The fish that habitate the world make it feel alive and bustling with energy and each fish is designed uniquely with different swim patterns and tendencies. To be brief, this game really makes you feel like an scuba-diving explorer.  Along with that, Austin Wintory makes his return to composing another excellently-done video game soundtrack. He did a fantastic job in Journey, and I personally think he outdid his work with ABZU. Some of the songs that play are so seamless that they help draw you further into the action or calm that happens within the game. One of my favorite tracks is 'Delphinus Delphis', that really captures the essence of swimming through a fast jetstream filled with millions of fish swimming about all around you. It captures the wonder, the danger, and excitement within ABZU wonderfully, and I think Wintory is definitely getting the recognition he deserves. I certainly hope he keeps going on to compose more video games, or even some movies in the future.  Well, it does sound like I like ABZU a lot, doesn't it? But you know me. I can never truly love anything, especially a game revolving around the sea. It reminds me of when I was a young boy, living alone on a small island in the Pacific when I would sleep alone, shivering beneath the palm tree as the waves would bash the eastern side of the island, as if to frighten me. I've been scared of the ocean ever since.  If you believed that story, congratulations. You're gullible.  No, what does bother me about ABZU is the laziness of the story-telling. For one, it relies on you befriending this shark that's introduced in the game but I didn't have much reason to do so. He acts very showy and aggresive, but after saving him he doesn't really do anything. And when they try to pull on your heartstrings, it just felt very rushed and forced.  Along with that, I groaned when I saw events unfurl in ABZU the exact same way they did in Flower and Journey. Yet again, there is an all-powerful, dying, destructive force that is imposing itself on the environment and nearly overpowers you, until you find the magical power of 'the first thing we pulled out of our a**es' and you finally crush the big, evil... thing and save the world! I was hoping it would do something a little different, but the writing fell back on the same conventions built on Flower and Journey which are, in my opinion, weak. I never felt that intimidated by the big-machine-thing because it didn't pose a real threat. I'd already restored the sea-coral-magic-things and the mines set up all over don't even kill you, they just stop you for a couple seconds. That's not scary. That's annoying and tedious.  The gameplay is also significantly weaker in ABZU than it was in Journey and more on par with Flower. Oftentimes, you're left to explore a large room with two switches put somewhere randomly around the room that will both open the door. It's not challenging or engaging. It's boring, and far too often does ABZU rely on the big-room-two-switches-one-door idea that it feels very lazily designed. In Journey, you often had to use teamwork or your own know-how to solve the puzzles set before you. They weren't that challenging, but they were something! With ABZU, it feels more like you're doing the same thing over and over. You swim down a jet stream, follow some whales, go through a giant robot door, find two switches, open a door, wash, rinse, and repeat.  I still think ABZU is worth playing, if you like this sort of game. I'm just disappointed that even with a fresh new design team, ABZU can't help but feel like just another game made by thatgamecompany, but this time it's underwater. It's certainly beautiful and excellently-scored, but the execution of the story is so bland and forgettable that I couldn't be bothered to remember it within the next week. But that scuba diving and underwater exploration was so engaging that I might go back and play ABZU simply for that pleasure alone. I'm giving ABZU a 7/10.  Also, don't worry about the warnings for having a controller in this game. It controls just fine with a keyboard and mouse. Take my word for it.

Surprising little plot twist that actually delighted me.   My only complaint is that the story element isn't as fleshed out as Journey's, or I'm missing it. I can gather quite a bit from the mosaics on the walls, but there's not enough to piece together the story as well as the small cutscenes in Journey did. I have little to no clue why these evil triangles exist, the significance of the magic water, or the temple, or the shark. I feel like I'm missing important context clues but if they're in game, I haven't seen them. A little more so that it was easily understandable would have pushed the game from the 9 I'm giving it into a 10/10. My other complaint is that I don't quite understand the hitboxes of the mines. My first playthrough, I only hit one. Second, I struck about seven of them, but I didn't seem to be closer to them than I was on my first run. So, that was a little offputting.   Oh: and when the game says a controller is strongly recommended? They aren't kidding. I can't imagine playing this with a keyboard and mouse. ABZU is a short and sweet adventure through a beautifully rendered underwater world. It is a fantastic experience marked by gorgeous visuals and score. While the game is short at ~2hrs long, it serves as a very relaxing break and lovely way to spend part of an evening.

Absolutely Breathtaking  ABZU is one of the rare few games where its goal is to take you on a spiritual journey, so it is of no surprise that the art director for Journey as well as Flower is leading the helm for this remarkable experience. ABZU draws many paralels to Journey with its story where not a single word is uttered and your imagination is set free to draw your own conclusions, as well as the stunning music that so elegantly draws you in to the experience and the beauty of the environment and the plethora of sea creatures in the many underwater edens. Yes, ABZU takes place almost entirely underwater, but unlike the other undersea games floating around Steam, ABZU is not a survival game, it is a broad but still linear narrative game based around art, exploration and relaxation. The only complaints I can mention are that the movement controls on a gamepad (XBOX 360 for me) can get some getting used to and occasionally I found myself swimming in circles. The other grievance I can mention, if it is a rather childish one, that the game was just a little longer, my end game time clocked in at 94 minutes. Even just a single level to bring it up to Jouney's length which I felt was perfect. I will still play it for many hours more to find all the hidden collectables and all the little secrets I'm sure are hiding in the deep, just a little forewarning for those that like big drawn out experiences.  Those aside, play this game. It is utter enrichment for the soul like its predicessors and give you imagination a fresh breath of air. If you got the cash to spare, go for it, I doubt you'll be disappointed. For others whose money is a little tighter, mark it on your wishlist and wait for a good sale to come around. But I assure you, ABZU is not an experience to be missed out on.

I'd reccomend this game, with headphones in. It's truly a unique experience

Like Flow, Flower & Journey before it, this is a gorgeous but brief experience. At first it could be mistaken for a graphics demo or fishtank screensaver, but as the game progresses there are some familiar emotional beats that the game hits to make you feel that you're getting more out of this than some painfully elementary puzzles. The moments of delight pay for everything else, including some clumsy controls and an aggravating camera.  Once it's over you will have three or four memorable experiences (more than many 30+ hour games can supply) but at two hours for a run-through you'd have to be crazy mad on fish or a serious lover of arthouse game experiences to buy this outside a sale.  A must-play for most, and I expect to play it at least twice.

This is a beautiful game.  If you played Journey and loved it, this is the true successor to Journey.  The game is only about an hour long but i recommend getting it on sale. Its not too hard and is definitley one of those 'games' that is more a piece of art than it is a traditional game; akin to Journey.  Unlike Journey, you're playing in a vibrant ocean. The narrative with this one is decent but also a little strange and heartwarming in a way. It's a bit of a rollercoaster and not totally up front and in your face.  I give this one a spaghetti and meatballs out of ten.

ABZU is my game of the year for 2016. It's short, but the art, sound, and story are all beautiful.   It's an amazing experience for the whole family, and we enjoyed exploring the underwater world and mystery of AZBU together. I also recommend the 'Meditation' mode of the game to anyone trying to sooth a tired and grumpy toddler to sleep. It has very calm music and visuals that can ease them into slumber.

I spend a good chuck of Christmas Day 2016 swimming around in this beautiful underwater world. It is not a game with combat, serious puzzles or really any challenges put in your way, it is a game of exploration and wondering at the amazing experience. Playing this game is a kind of meditation on tranquility, similar in parts to their other game 'Flower'. Make sure you have a game pad and decent audio and visual hardware, and you're in for a treat.
The Best 2 hours of gameplay you can get. Magical, peaceful, and takes you on a trip. Close to Journey, but who cares, at that point I need more of these kind of game, so it did not bother me

A fun experience. Vivid colors, beautiful sounds, and a simple but interesting story make for fun way to spend an evening. In total it takes a couple hours to complete but is really fun and enjoyable the whole time.
It's like a Pixar Short Film that you can play.

This game is awe-inspiring. There is beauty in every corner of this game. It has a simple story well told through environment and music, but that really isnt the draw for Abzu. If you find joy and inspiration in the sea, or even nature in general, I cant think of a game I could recommend more than this.
This game brings stunning visuals, simplistic controls, and awe inspiring sound design to their peak possibilities. This game is a feast for the senses; with its low price, it is well worth it.

The amound and love and care that went into the soudntrack, the aquatic creatures, and the enviroments is mind blowing. I couldn't help but explore every nook and cranny. this game will stick with me forever

Short and gorgeous underwater exploration game. It hits many of the same beats as Journey, but that's not a bad thing! The controls can be a little wonky, but that's about the only negative I have. If you enjoy relaxing, beautiful games, this is a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.

I bought this game the day it came out, the preview on the steam home page peaked my interest, the positive reviews sealed the deal for me, most reviewers called this game 'an experience' and I strongly agree. Running the graphics on the highest settings, and the new age sound track make this game a feast for the eyes and ears, and a completely immersive experience. What I liked about the game was having no idea what the hell I was supposed to do, learning as I went was part of the fun. I enjoyed it so much I have played it through twice, and I still have missed a few meditation spots. I don't want to give away any spoilers, but I thorough enjoyed the game, it doesn't focus on high scores or survival, but more exploration and completion.

This is a brief and relaxing artsy-fartsy experience with vibrant and unique visuals, sweeping orchestral scores, authentic marine life all over the joint and of course, ancient aqua Egyptians. Not sure what the story is about, but phallic coral obelisks, angry triangles and shark patronuses aside, this is a pretty chill game.

Absolutely incredible. It's a bit short, and I'd like some larger areas to explore, but for what it's already got, it's pretty great.  Would recommend, if you like water and fish.

Excellent game.  I can't really say anything about it without comparing it to Journey on the PS3/4. It is essentially an underwater Journey. It has beautiful cel shaded graphics that are some of the best I've ever seen (it happens to be my favourite visual style for games), and an excellent soundtrack by Austin Wintory, who also composed the music for Journey.  It's a very short game, and only took 1.5 hours for me to complete, although this type of game has very good replay value. I can't really find any fault with it, but it'd be cool if it had some level of multiplayer, where you and another player who are in the same area can seamlessly integrate into the one game (this is what Journey did, and it was so good). You can't really interact with them, but it adds a very cool sense of companionship when somebody joins you on your great journey.
Beautiful, immersive exploration game in the ocean. Calm, peaceful game. Great marine life and graphics.

Abzu is a difficult game to recommend... Not because it is bad, but for its incredible short duration. The game roughly took me 3 hours to complete (without getting everything), however I must say that getting it on sales and finishing it yesterday, was a nice way to start the weekend. I don't know why, but this game made me see again, that videogame industry is full of authentic Art pieces, and Abzu is one of those. You'll discover a world full of colour, realistic animations, lots of fish species and a wonderful OST. So, if you appreciate Art in videogames, I recommend Abzu to you.

Sick of your life? Feel miserable? Need a timeout and your friend just ate your KitKat? Just chill, sit back, grab your controller and get this game. I guarantee you that it's gonna make you feel better... much much better. You'll be smiling again in no time (±4 hours). Happy times, happy times indeed.

ABZU is a game that is heavily inspired by the games Journey and Flower. This has some of the most amazing visuals I've seen in a game, scene after scene of striking art design. The soundtrack is great too, made by the same composer as the soundtrack for Journey. I would highly reccomend this game to anybody looking for a stress-reducing game. If you're looking for in depth gameplay, you will be disappointed, there's very little challenge to it and there are only a few collectibles to find. But if you're looking for a game to replay over and over just to take in the beautiful sights and sounds and become immersed in this underwater world, then you have found the right game.

There are games and then there are works of art. Abzu is the latter. A beautiful interactive masterpiece set to an amazing score by Austin Wintory. If you loved Journey (and who didn't?) then you will love Abzu. It might not be quite as good as Journey, but it comes darn close and is amazing in its own right.

I don't know what other word to describe this game other than... stunning. Just stunning. From the visuals to the soundtrack to the compelling story, this game was a pleasure to play. Loved it from beginning to end.

This game is the closest thing you'll get to playing Journey on PC. It is absolutely worth every penny if you can stomach paying full price for a 1.5-2 h expereince. It is even more worth it if you wait for a sale.  Beautiful, artistic and even slightly emotional. You owe it to yourself to play this if you've had the slightest interest in the games produced by ThatGameCompany on the Playstation 3.

A short, relaxing experience.  I'm recommending this, but honestly I'm sad to say I can only recommend it at sale price. If you really really like fish and swimming it might be worth the full price.  I loved Flower and Journey and I was glad to see some elements from both in this game. This comes close, but sadly does not match those experiences. Which is not a total dis as that is a hard thing to achieve.  What ABZU succeeds in is creating a lovely environment and an interesting main character you control. There are also lots and lots of different sea creatures to discover through the game and a 'meditate' mode that lets you just pick a fish and let the camera follow it around while it does its thing. There is an element of armchair archaeologist where you get to try and fugure out what happened to the game world (and who you are). There are even a few good emotional scenes.  It is short and I don't feel it offers much replay value, but I feel the experience was worth the price of admission.
Honestly wasn't expecting much when I started the game. Was pleasantly surprised. Would strongly recommend this game, possibly along with some patience.
SO BEAUTIFUL. make sure to watch on a very large screen and your hardware can handle the ultra settings. I feel like I just went to another world for a couple of hours.

Without hesitation, without competition, my favourite game I've ever played. I played it all in one sitting, mesmerised. I have a huge love for whales and sharks, as well as always having had a deep fondness for the ocean and marine life in general, so this game was... masterful. Absolutely incredible for me. I fell in love immediately, and couldn't rip myself away from the game for even a minute.  If you have even the slightest interest in or fascination for the ocean, I highly recommend you play ABZÛ. It's a gorgeous, fascinating, and enthralling game from start to finish. Highly recommended.  10/10  SPOILERS:  I have to admit I cried when the Great White died. It's my favourite shark, second only to the Whale Shark, and I was sad to see it die just after having befriended it. Having it come back to life and destroying the ominous, creepy pyramids by its side was one of the most satisfying things I've experienced in a game. Wonderfully executed build-up and pay-off.

Flower was fun as you zipped through the air at the speed if sound, reviving your fellow flowers and expanding the play area.  Journey was fun as you tested how far you could leap with every new upgrade, rode various scarf-creatures, and surfed the sand.  This game is pretty, but it's not much fun.

If you love exploring, this beautiful game will reward you! The story itself only takes a couple of hours to play through, yet I was surprised how the simple adventure captivated me. Taking the time to explore this amazing world is a lot of fun. My heart still pounds with a tinge of fear diving deep down into the darkness in the middle chapters, yet the excitement of what I may see takes over. This game gives you a chance to see and explore all kinds of underwater species, some of which you may never get to see in today's world. I had great fun exploring the ABZU world in detail myself, before turning to some great guides for help in finding the remaining collectables. I bought this game on sale, but it was certainly more than worth it!
